head.title: Welcome to the dpytest documentation! — dpytest 0.7.0 documentation

section.p: The dpytest library is designed to make testing of discord bots easy and painless.

The library is currently in its infancy, and only supports a subset of the discord API. Also, the API is not yet finalized, and may change somewhat rapidly. Breaking changes can be expected until the library hits version 1.0.

body.div:
©2020, CraftSpider.
| Powered by Sphinx 7.0.1 & Alabaster 0.7.13
| Page source

div.p: Please activate JavaScript to enable the search functionality.
Searching for multiple words only shows matches that contain all words.

section.p: Welcome to dpytest, a python library for testing discord bots written using discord.py. This tutorial will explain how to install dpytest and set it up in your project, and write a simple test. If you already know how to install libraries with pip, you probably want to skip to Using Pytest.
To start with, you should install dpytest with pip. This will look a bit different, depending if you're on Windows or Mac/Linux:

li.p: Windows: py -m pip install dpytest
Linux: python3 -m pip install dpytest

section.p: Once installed, you will need to import dpytest before you can use it. As it is an extension to discord.py, it goes into the discord.py extensions module. So, the most basic usage of dpytest would look like this:

One problem that could happen is that the sent_queue is shared between the tests. So in order not to mess between your tests (verify() pops one message from the queue, so in general, you won't need to do anything) you can explicitly call empty_queue(), as shown in the next example (and later, in the conftests.py).
If that looks like a lot of code just to run tests, don't worry, there's a better way! We can use pytest, a popular Python testing library.
Next Tutorial: Using Pytest

body.div:
©2020, CraftSpider.
| Powered by Sphinx 7.0.1 & Alabaster 0.7.13
| Page source

section.p: Here will be found tutorials for using dpytest practically, starting with the fundamentals and building up to more advanced usage. For now, there isn't much yet, but expect this to change as the library grows.

ul.li: Previous: Welcome to the dpytest documentation!

body.div:
©2020, CraftSpider.
| Powered by Sphinx 7.0.1 & Alabaster 0.7.13
| Page source

section.p: So, you already have dpytest installed, and can import it. However, setting up a client for every test is a pain. The library is designed to work well with pytest (Thus the name), and it can make writing tests much easier. In the following tutorial we'll show how to set it up.
pytest can be installed through pip the same way dpytest is. Once that's done, using it is as easy as:

li.p: Windows: py -m pytest
Linux: python3 -m pytest

section.p: pytest will detect any functions starting with 'test' in directories it searches, and run them. It also supports a feature we will use heavily, called 'fixtures'. Fixtures are functions that do some common test setup, and then can be used in tests to always perform that setup, they can also return an object that will be passed to the test. Finally, they allow you to perform test teardown, cleaning message queue for example. See https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/how-to/fixtures.html#teardown-cleanup-aka-fixture-finalization

The final piece of this is pytest-asyncio, a library for allowing pytest to run async tests. It is automatically installed when you get dpytest from pip, so you don't need to worry about installing it.
Putting all this together, we can rewrite our previous tests to look like this:

pre.span: # empty the global message queue as test teardown

section.p: Much less writing the same code over and over again, and tests will be automatically run by pytest, then the results output in a nice pretty format once it's done.

As you write tests, you may want to split them into multiple files. One file for testing this cog, another for ensuring reactions work right. As it stands, you'll still need to copy your bot fixture into every file. To fix this, you need to create a file named conftest.py at the root of where you're putting your tests. If you haven't already, you should probably put them all in their own directory. Then you can put any fixtures you want in conftest.py, and pytest will let you use them in any other test file. pytest also recognizes certain function names with special meanings, for example pytest_sessionfinish will be run after all tests are done if defined in your conftest.
An example conftest.py might look like this:

pre.span: # empty the global message queue as test teardown
""" Code to execute after all tests. """
# dat files are created when using attachements

section.p: With that, you should be ready to use dpytest with your bot.

li.p: I wrote a fixture, but I can't use the bot

section.p: Make sure your tests take a parameter with the exact same name as the fixture, pytest runs them based on name, including capitalization.

li.p: I use dpytest.verify().message() and it fails but it shouldn't
dpytest.get_message() returns a message from another test

section.p: Make sure you properly emptied the queue in the previous test, otherwise you could have remaining messages from previous tests messing up.
This is currently the end of the tutorials. Take a look at the Runner Documentation to see all the things you can do with dpytest.

body.div:
©2020, CraftSpider.
| Powered by Sphinx 7.0.1 & Alabaster 0.7.13
| Page source

section.p: Module for 'server-side' state during testing. This module should contain methods for altering said server-side state, which then are responsible for triggering a parse_* call in the configured client state to inform the bot of the change.
This setup matches discord's actual setup, where an HTTP call triggers a change on the server, which is then sent back to the bot as an event which is parsed and dispatched.

dl.dt: class BackendState(messages: Dict[int, List[Dict[str, str | int | bool | Dict[str, JsonVal] | List[JsonVal]]]], state: FakeState)¶

dd.p: The dpytest backend, with all the state it needs to hold to be able to pretend to be discord. Generally only used internally, but exposed through get_state()

dl.dt: class FakeRequest(status: int, reason: str)¶

dd.p: A fake web response, for use with discord HTTPExceptions

A mock implementation of an HTTPClient. Instead of actually sending requests to discord, it triggers a runner callback and calls the dpytest backend to update any necessary state and trigger any necessary fake messages to the client.

dl.dt: async request(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → NoReturn¶

div.p: Overloaded to raise a NotImplemented error informing the user that the requested operation isn't yet supported by dpytest. To fix this, the method call that triggered this error should be overloaded below to instead trigger a callback and call the appropriate backend function.

dl.dt: Parameters:

li.p: args – Arguments provided to the request
kwargs – Keyword arguments provided to the request

roles – Existing roles in the guild or None

id_num – ID of the guild, or nothing to auto-generate

roles – New role list for the guild

colour – New color for the role

section.p: Module containing registered callbacks for various events. These events are how various parts of discord.py can communicate with the frontend runner or a user's custom runner setup. These callbacks should not be used to trigger backend changes, that is the responsibility of the library internals.

dl.dt: async dispatch_event(event: str, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → None¶

div.p: Dispatch an event to a set handler, if one exists. Will ignore handler errors, just print a log

dl.dt: Parameters:

li.p: event – Name of the event to dispatch
args – Arguments to the callback
kwargs – Keyword arguments to the callback

dl.dt: set_callback(cb: Callable[[...], Coroutine[None, None, None]], event: str) → None¶

div.p: Set the callback to use for a specific event

dl.dt: Parameters:

li.p: cb – Callback to use
event – Name of the event to register for

div.p: Get the current callback for an event, or raise an exception if one isn't set

dl.dt: Parameters:

dd.p: event – Event to get callback for

dl.dt: Returns:

dd.p: Callback for event, if one is set

div.p: Remove the callback set for an event, returning it, or None if one isn't set

dl.dt: Parameters:

dd.p: event – Event to remove callback for

dl.dt: Returns:

dd.p: Callback that was previously set or None

section.p: Module for (mostly) stateless creation/destructuring of discord.py objects. Primarily a utility for the rest of the library, which often needs to convert between objects and JSON at various stages.

section.p: The dpytest API is split among several modules, each of which is documented here

section.p: Main module for setting up and running tests using dpytest. Handles configuration of a bot, and setup of the discord environment.
All public functions in this module are re-exported at discord.ext.test, this is the primary entry point for users of the library and most of what they should interact with

dl.dt: See also:

code.class: xref py py-mod docutils literal notranslate

dl.dt: class RunnerConfig(client: Client, guilds: List[Guild], channels: List[GuildChannel], members: List[Member])¶

dd.p: Exposed discord test configuration Contains the current client, and lists of faked objects

div.p: Decorator to enforce that configuration is completed before the decorated function is called.

dl.dt: Parameters:
Returns:

dd.p: Function with added check for configuration being setup
Ensure that all dpy related coroutines have completed or been cancelled. If any dpy coroutines are currently running, this will also wait for those.
Ensure that all dpy related coroutines have completed or been cancelled. This will only wait for dpy related coroutines, not any other coroutines currently running.

div.p: Allow the user to retrieve the most recent message sent by the bot

dl.dt: Parameters:

dd.p: peek – If true, message will not be removed from the queue

dl.dt: Returns:

dd.p: Most recent message from the queue

div.p: Allow the user to retrieve an embed in a message sent by the bot

dl.dt: Parameters:

dd.p: peek – do not remove the message from the queue of messages

dl.dt: Returns:

dd.p: Embed of the most recent message in the queue
Empty the current message queue. Waits for all events to complete to ensure queue is not immediately added to after running.

li.p: content – Content of the message
channel – Channel to send to, or index into the config list
member – Member sending the message, or index into the config list
attachments – Message attachments to include, as file paths.

div.p: Set the permission override for a channel, as if set by another user.

dl.dt: Parameters:

li.p: target – User or Role the permissions override is being set for
channel – Channel the permissions are being set on
overrides – The permissions to use, as an object. Conflicts with using kwargs
kwargs – The permissions to use, as a set of keys and values. Conflicts with using overrides

div.p: Add a role to a member, as if added by another user.

li.p: member – Member to add the role to
role – Role to be added

role – Role to remove

div.p: Get the current runner configuration

dl.dt: Returns:
configure(client: Client, guilds: int | List[str] = 1, text_channels: int | List[str] = 1, voice_channels: int | List[str] = 1, members: int | List[str] = 1) → None¶

div.p: Set up the runner configuration. This should be done before any tests are run.

dl.dt: Parameters:

li.p: client – Client to configure with. Should be the bot/client that is going to be tested.
guilds – Number or list of names of guilds to start the configuration with. Default is 1
text_channels – Number or list of names of text channels in each guild to start with. Default is 1
voice_channels – Number or list of names of voice channels in each guild to start with. Default is 1.
members – Number or list of names of members in each guild (other than the client) to start with. Default is 1.

section.p: Mock implementation of a discord.state.ConnectionState. Overwrites a Client's default state, allowing hooking of its methods and support for test-related features.

dl.dt: class FakeState(client: Client, http: HTTPClient, user: ClientUser | None = None, loop: AbstractEventLoop | None = None)¶

dd.p: A mock implementation of a ConnectionState. Overrides methods that would otherwise cause issues, and implements functionality such as disabling dispatch temporarily.

dl.dt: __init__(client: Client, http: HTTPClient, user: ClientUser | None = None, loop: AbstractEventLoop | None = None) → None¶

dd.p: Stop dispatching events to the client, if we are
Start dispatching events to the client, if we aren't already

dl.dt: async query_members(guild: Guild, query: str, limit: int, user_ids: int, cache: bool, presences: bool) → None¶
async chunk_guild(guild: Guild, *, wait: bool = True, cache: bool | None = None)¶

dd.p: Need to make sure that FakeVoiceChannels are created when this is called to create VoiceChannels. Otherwise, guilds would not be set up correctly.

dl.dt: Parameters:

dd.p: data – info to use in channel creation.

section.p: Utility functions that don't have a place anywhere else. If it doesn't sound like it fits anywhere else, and it's small, it probably goes here.

dl.dt: embed_eq(embed1: Embed | None, embed2: Embed | None) → bool¶
activity_eq(act1: Activity | None, act2: Activity | None) → bool¶
embed_proxy_eq(embed_proxy1, embed_proxy2)¶
class PeekableQueue(maxsize=0, *, loop=None)¶

dd.p: An extension of an asyncio queue with a peek message, so other code doesn't need to rely on unstable internal artifacts

div.p: Peek the current last value in the queue, or raise an exception if there are no values

dl.dt: Returns:

dd.p: Last value in the queue, assuming there are any

section.p: Main module for supporting predicate-style assertions. Handles checking various state matches the desired outcome.
All verify types should be re-exported at discord.ext.test, this is the primary entry point for assertions in the library

dl.dt: See also:

code.class: xref py py-mod docutils literal notranslate

dd.p: Builder for message verifications. When done building, should be asserted.

div.p: Only check whether content/embed list/etc contain the desired input, not that they necessarily match exactly

dl.dt: Returns:

div.p: Don't remove the verified message from the queue

dl.dt: Returns:

div.p: Check that no message was sent

dl.dt: Returns:

div.p: Check that the message content matches the input

dl.dt: Parameters:

dd.p: content – Content to match against, or None to ensure no content

dl.dt: Returns:

div.p: Check that the message embed matches the input

dl.dt: Parameters:

dd.p: embed – Embed to match against, or None to ensure no embed

dl.dt: Returns:

div.p: Check that the message attachment matches the input

dl.dt: Parameters:

dd.p: attach – Attachment path to match against, or None to ensure no attachment

dl.dt: Returns:

dd.p: Builder for activity verifications. When done building, should be asserted

div.p: Ensure that the bot activity exactly matches the passed activity. Most restrictive possible check.

dl.dt: Parameters:
Returns:

div.p: Check that the activity name matches the input

dl.dt: Parameters:
Returns:

div.p: Check the the activity url matches the input

dl.dt: Parameters:
Returns:

div.p: Check the activity type matches the input

dl.dt: Parameters:
Returns:

dd.p: Base for all kinds of verification builders. Used as an intermediate step for the return of verify().

div.p: Verify a message

dl.dt: Returns:

div.p: Verify the bot's activity

dl.dt: Returns:

div.p: Verification entry point. Call to begin building a verification.

Warning: All verification builders do nothing until asserted, used in an if statement, or otherwise converted into a bool. They will raise RuntimeWarning if this isn't done to help catch possible errors.

dl.dt: Returns:

section.p: Mock implementation of a discord.gateway.DiscordWebSocket. Overwrites a Client's default websocket, allowing hooking of its methods to update the backend and provide callbacks.

dl.dt: class FakeWebSocket(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any)¶

dd.p: A mock implementation of a DiscordWebSocket. Instead of actually sending information to discord, it simply triggers calls to the dpytest backend, as well as triggering runner callbacks.
